conclusion: To determine the difference in electric potential energy of the small ball when it reaches the highest point compared to its electric potential energy at point O, we need to follow these steps:
The ball is subjected to two forces: the electric force \( \vec{F}_E \) and the gravitational force \( \vec{F}_g \).
The electric force \( \vec{F}_E \) acts in the direction of the electric field \( \vec{E} \), which is horizontal.

premise: The electric force \( \vec{F}_E \) can be expressed as \( \vec{F}_E = q\vec{E} \), where \( q \) is the charge of the ball.
The gravitational force \( \vec{F}_g \) is \( \vec{F}_g = mg \), where \( m \) is the mass of the ball and \( g \) is the acceleration due to gravity.

conclusion: The ball moves along a straight line at an angle \( \theta \) to the horizontal.

premise: The component of the electric force along the path is \( F_{E,\text{path}} = qE \cos \theta \).
conclusion: The component of the electric force along the path is \( qE \cos \theta \).

premise: The component of the gravitational force along the path is \( F_{g,\text{path}} = mg \sin \theta \).
conclusion: The component of the gravitational force along the path is \( mg \sin \theta \).

premise: The net force along the path is the vector sum of the components of the electric and gravitational forces.
conclusion: The net force along the path is \( F_{\text{net}} = qE \cos \theta - mg \sin \theta \).

premise: The work done by the electric force as the ball moves from point \( O \) to the highest point is \( W_E = F_{E,\text{path}} \cdot d \), where \( d \) is the distance traveled along the path.
conclusion: The work done by the electric force is \( W_E = qE \cos \theta \cdot d \).

premise: The distance \( d \) can be expressed in terms of the vertical displacement \( h \) as \( d = \frac{h}{\sin \theta} \).
